prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 HCO+/HCN (setting 1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a Band 3 setting aimed at HCO+/HCN

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The bandwidth and spectral resolution of the spectral windows vary from baseband to baseband. The main goal of this block are the HCO+ and HCN lines. Other lines are added as far as LO settings allow. See Table 1 for an overview. BB4 is aimed at the dust continuum. FDM was preferred above TDM as molecular emission may be present in the 2 GHz around the 100 GHz center frequency. Second, a continuum baseband will greatly aid the calibration as it increases the aggregate bandwidth.

The angular scale that is required is 0.4", which equates to a size-scale of about 0.13 pc at a distance of 60 kpc. This angular scale is as close to the filament width seen in molecular clouds in the Milky Way as we can get without observing the long baseline mode. The largest angular scale that needs to be retrieved is set at 90 arcseconds. This equals the angle on the sky projected by the 12CO emission (see Fig. 1). None of the molecules is expected to span larger areas. Even though some molecules may be able to trace CO-dark gas, most will not be seen in areas of high density where CO is present due to their chemistry. Most, if not all, emission will span much smaller angles on the sky.

Sensitivity limits (per channel) are estimated using the 13CO 2--1 emission seen by APEX within the COSSA program and using average line ratios seen by SEST (Heijkala et al. 1999) for the SMC. 13CO 2--1 was seen with an integrated intensity of 84 Jy km s-1 and a peak flux density of 40 Jy. If we assume 13CO to be smoothly distributed over the APEX beam, a lower limit of 70 mJy/beam in a 1 km/s bin is derived, much higher than the 10 mJy requested. Most lines were detected in ratios ranging from 1/3rd to 1/5th of 13CO 2-1, justifying our lower limit and providing at least 2sigma detections in even the weaker lines. As such we expect detections in most, if not all, lines targetted. Deviation from the smooth distribution is expected and will greatly increase the detection rate. In truth, the amount of structure and contrast between the filaments is important.
To reach our scientific objectives a resolution of 1 km/s is needed with the exception of BB4, which provides the continuum. Given the line widths seen in CO (both 2--1 and 1--0) and 13CO (van Kempen et al., in prep, Muller et al., in prep), line widths ranging from 3 to 5 km/s are expected, providing at least 3-5 spectral elements. Most windows the best resolution that can be obtained without going over the maximum data rate (ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 km/s).

The bandwidth and spectral resolution of the spectral windows vary from baseband to baseband. The main goal of this block are the DCO+ and DCN lines. Other lines are added as far as LO settings allow. See Table 1 for an overview of targetted lines. For both BB3 and BB4, a resolution of 1.2 km/s is set. As these two baseband will be combined to form the continuum and are targetted on lines with lower priority this is acceptable.

The angular scale that is required is 0.4", which equates to a size-scale of about 0.13 pc at a distance of 60 kpc. This angular scale is as close to the filament width seen in molecular clouds in the Milky Way as we can get without observing the long baseline mode. The largest angular scale that needs to be retrieved is set at 90 arcseconds. This equals the angle on the sky projected by the 12CO emission (see Fig. 1). None of the molecules is expected to span larger areas. Even though some molecules may be able to trace CO-dark gas, most will not be seen in areas of high density where CO is present due to their chemistry. Most, if not all, emission will span much smaller angles on the sky.

Sensitivity limits (per channel) are estimated using the 13CO 2--1 emission seen by APEX within the COSSA program and using average line ratios seen by SEST (Heijkala et al. 1999) for the SMC. 13CO 2--1 was seen with an integrated intensity of 84 Jy km s-1 and a peak flux density of 40 Jy. If we assume 13CO to be smoothly distributed over the APEX beam, a lower limit of 70 mJy/beam in a 1 km/s bin is derived, much higher than the 7 mJy requested. Most lines were detected in ratios ranging from 1/3rd to 1/5th of 13CO 2-1, justifying our lower limit and providing at least 2sigma detections in even the weaker lines, as well as the deuterated line in this setting. As such we expect detections in most, if not all, lines targetted. Deviation from the smooth distribution is expected and will greatly increase the detection rate. In truth, the amount of structure and contrast between the filaments is important.
To reach our scientific objectives a resolution of 1 km/s is needed with the exception of BB4, which provides the continuum. Given the line widths seen in CO (both 2--1 and 1--0) and 13CO (van Kempen et al., in prep, Muller et al., in prep), line widths ranging from 3 to 5 km/s are expected, providing at least 3-5 spectral elements. Most windows the best resolution that can be obtained without going over the maximum data rate (ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 km/s).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 CO (setting 2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a Band 3 setting to image CO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The bandwidth and spectral resolution of the spectral windows vary from baseband to baseband, aimed at maximizing the number of lines to be targetting. The main goal of this block is the CO line. Other lines are added as far as LO settings allow. See Table 1 for an overview. BB4 is aimed at the dust continuum. FDM was preferred above TDM as molecular emission from 13-methanol may be present in the 2 GHz around the 114 GHz center frequency. Second, a continuum baseband will greatly aid the calibration as it increases the aggregate bandwidth above 1 GHz.

The angular scale that is required is 0.4", which equates to a size-scale of about 0.13 pc at a distance of 60 kpc. This angular scale is as close to the filament width seen in molecular clouds in the Milky Way as we can get without observing the long baseline mode. The largest angular scale that needs to be retrieved is set at 90 arcseconds. This equals the angle on the sky projected by the 12CO emission (see Fig. 1). None of the molecules is expected to span larger areas. Even though some molecules may be able to trace CO-dark gas, most will not be seen in areas of high density where CO is present due to their chemistry. Most, if not all, emission will span much smaller angles on the sky.

Sensitivity limits (per channel) are estimated using the 13CO 2--1 emission seen by APEX within the COSSA program and using average line ratios seen by SEST (Heijkala et al. 1999) for the SMC. 13CO 2--1 was seen with an integrated intensity of 84 Jy km s-1 and a peak flux density of 40 Jy. If we assume 13CO to be smoothly distributed over the APEX beam, a lower limit of 70 mJy/beam in a 1 km/s bin is derived, much higher than the 10 mJy requested. Most lines were detected in ratios ranging from 1/3rd to 1/5th of 13CO 2-1, justifying our lower limit and providing at least 2sigma detections in even the weaker lines. As such we expect detections in most, if not all, lines targetted. Deviation from the smooth distribution is expected and will greatly increase the detection rate. In truth, the amount of structure and contrast between the filaments is important.
To reach our scientific objectives a resolution of 1 km/s is needed with the exception of BB4, which provides the continuum. Given the line widths seen in CO (both 2--1 and 1--0) and 13CO (van Kempen et al., in prep, Muller et al., in prep), line widths ranging from 3 to 5 km/s are expected, providing at least 3-5 spectral elements. Most windows the best resolution that can be obtained without going over the maximum data rate (ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 km/s).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: nderstanding the chemical composition of the molecular component of the Interstellar Medium (ISM) at low metallicity (10% solar) is essential for comprehending the most ubiquitous mode of star formation; low-mass star formation in the outer regions of galaxies, satellite galaxies or dwarf galaxies. For virtually all galaxies but the Milky Way, this component cannot be derived directly, as any structure within GMCs is heavily diluted within even the best resolutions. For the first time, the resolution and sensitivity of ALMA allows us to observe the nearby low-metallicy clouds in the SMC down to the scale of individual filaments. We propose to use ALMA to study the composition, and its variations, of low-metallicity molecular ISM by observing the most quiescent and pristine region in the SMC (N12) with the goal to understand molecular enrichment in low-metallicity ISM. We plan to resolve, for the very first time, the chemical components within individual filaments of a low metallicity GMC. We will target various ground or low-lying transitions of common di- and triatomic molecules in Bands 3 and 4, all known ISM tracers.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Nobeyama Radio Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Nobeyama Radio Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
